page_content:
# Bug report

## Describe the bug

When defining two overloaded functions in the database schema only one will be listed in the Studio API documentation.

For example:

```
create function always_true(date_start date, date_end date)
    returns boolean
    language sql
    as $$
        select true;
    $$;

create function always_true(date_start date, duration interval)
    returns boolean
    language sql
    as $$
        select true;
    $$;
```

## To Reproduce

1. Clone [Repository reproducing issue](https://github.com/snorremd/supabase-overloaded-functions-missing-docs).
2. Run `supabase start`
3. Go to [API -> Stored Procedures -> Always true](http://localhost:54323/project/default/api?rpc=always_true)
4. See only one function overload is documented

## Expected behavior

Expected both function overloads to be documented.

## Screenshots

![Screenshot from 2022-08-10 12-19-46](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/781014/183878784-97f40887-ed26-46c1-949c-6bc7433f1b39.png)

## System information

Latest version of development environment

- OS: Ubuntu 22.10 (but not relevant)
- Supabase CLI: 0.38.3
- Supabase Studio: latest (sha256:50d189ac8716d91f5f738d0020a2a8f96fc07b62a3558ab9e97c16dee0682816)
- Supabase Postgres-meta:v0.42.1
- Postgrest: v9.0.1.20220802
- Postgres: 14.1.0.34

## Additional context

Function overloads are great when you want to provide multiple ways of passing relevant parameters. While they do work in practice it would be hard for people to use the functions without reading the SQL migration files.

metadata.title: Support function overloads in documentation
metadata.creator: snorremd

page_content:
# Bug report
Database views are not created after adding them to a migration file

## Describe the bug
Adding a view in a migration file does not make that view available in the UI.  Adding the view in the seed.sql file that's executed after the migration files does allow the view to be visible within the UI.

This also makes it difficult to add migration files for RLS policies on a View since the migration file doesn't create the actual view.

A clear and concise description of what the bug is.

## To Reproduce
Step 1 
```BASH
supabase db migration new create_view
```

`migrations/create_view.sql`
```SQL
CREATE VIEW view_name AS
  SELECT 
    id
  FROM public[table_name];
```

Visit [Local Supabase UI](http://localhost:54323/project/default/editor)
View is not available

Adding RLS policies to the created view also fails
Following Step 1
```SQL
create policy "Policy name"
  ON view_name for SELECT
  USING (
    TRUE
  );

// View does not exist
```

**Adding the `CREATE VIEW` to `seed.sql`**
Adding Step 1 in the seed.sql file that runs following the migrations does create the View and the View is visible in the UI

## Expected behavior

Can create views and view policies in migration files from the CLI

metadata.title: Views not available in the UI when created with migration file using CLI
metadata.creator: drewbietron

# Bug report

## Describe the bug

As the title states, when I apply a diff from a staging project to a production project using supabase's docker image, for the `public` schema only: `supabase/pgadmin-schema-diff --schema public` 

I noticed that I get a handful of `ERROR:  must be member of role "supabase_admin"` errors in the output. Otherwise, all tables, triggers, functions, and function hooks appear to be migrated successfully. 

I also found it odd the first line generated by that docker image in the `.sql` file is invalid SQL:

```
NOTE: Configuring authentication for DESKTOP mode.
```

## To Reproduce

Steps to reproduce the behavior, please provide code snippets or a repository:

1. Create two supabase projects
2. Generate a difference script using `supabase/pgadmin-schema-diff --schema public`
3. Apply the difference script to the desired project: `psql -h db.yoursupabaseurl.supabase.co -p 5432 -d postgres -U postgres -a -f database_schema_diff.sql`
4. See the errors from `psql`'s output

## Expected behavior

No errors at all when I try to apply the schema diff. (The target database in this case was a freshly installed supabase project)

## System information

I think all system info is irrelevant

## Additional context

Found some other discussions not directly related but it mentions the `supabase_admin` role: https://github.com/supabase/supabase/issues/1416

page_content:
Per: https://discord.com/channels/839993398554656828/993889903546998824

# Improve documentation

## Link 

https://supabase.com/docs/reference/javascript/contains
https://supabase.com/docs/reference/javascript/containedby

## Describe the problem

The current examples in the filter documentation seem to make assumptions about our knowledge of the nonexistence table they reference with their sample data/names. 

The topicality can be inferred somewhat, it's currently unclear what precisely the correlation is between the data being obtained from a column, and the column's relationship to that same data.

Additional confusion arises with specific filters like  "contains" and "containedBy"; they read as if they're opposites conceptually, but in the writing out of the function the placement of both the column and data to be filtered is (necessarily, for construction's sake) the same.

## Describe the improvement

I propose adding a visual frame of reference. If the non-existent table exists, I could see the data relationships and understand how each piece of data is acted upon, and/or how it is compartmentalized.

## Additional context

The PostgreSQL documentation has examples pages where they say in plain language how sidedness is handled when listing out different kinds of operations.  It may be useful, for the API functionality, to open each filter doc being abundantly clear in the same manner, i.e. "Contains takes the data and sees if the column contains it."

metadata.title: Update specific filters' documentation to provide context to meanings and sample data
metadata.creator: vincentjflorio

page_content:
# Bug report

## Describe the bug

When a column is designated as a Primary Key, the "Is Unique" flag does not appear in the Table Editor settings. This behavior makes sense when a single column is the Primary key, but is frustrating to deal with when you are using a composite primary key where a unique combination of 2 or more columns is the primary key.

Since the "Is Unique" flag is hidden, you can run into a uniqueness violations when writing to the table and not know why. 

## To Reproduce

1. Go to the Table Editor
2. Designate 2 columns as Primary Keys
3. Attempt to edit a column's "Is Unique" status
4. See error

## Expected behavior

1. Go to the Table Editor
2. Designate 2 columns as Primary Keys
3. Attempt to edit a columns "Is Unique" status
4. See the columns "is unique" status

## System information
Web Table Editor

metadata.title: "Is Unique" Toggle is Hidden on Column that is Part of a Table's Composite Primary Key
metadata.creator: raparri01

page_content:
# Feature request

## Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

We're self-hosting Supabase via Docker (it's amazing, thank you!) and one of the issues we have to deal with is safely storing/passing secrets to the containers.  It would be great if Supabase supported [Docker Secrets](https://docs.docker.com/engine/swarm/secrets), and `*_FILE` versions of the variables that hold secrets, so that we can pass a secrets file vs. the raw value:

```yml
services:
  studio:
    container_name: supabase-studio
    image: supabase/studio:latest
    restart: unless-stopped
    ports:
      - ${STUDIO_PORT}:3000/tcp
    environment:
      STUDIO_PG_META_URL: http://meta:8080
      POSTGRES_PASSWORD_FILE: /run/secrets/postgres_password

      SUPABASE_URL: http://kong:8000
      SUPABASE_REST_URL: ${PUBLIC_REST_URL}
      SUPABASE_ANON_KEY_FILE: /run/secrets/anon_key
      SUPABASE_SERVICE_KEY_FILE: /run/secrets/service_key
    secrets:
      - postgres_password
      - anon_key
      - service_key
  ...
```

The current `SUPABASE_SERVICE_KEY` variable could still be supported alongside `SUPABASE_SERVICE_KEY_FILE`, and the same for all of the secrets.  This would let current code continue to work, but migrate to a more secure method of injecting secrets.

## Describe the solution you'd like

[Docker really wants users](https://docs.docker.com/engine/swarm/secrets/#build-support-for-docker-secrets-into-your-images) to use `FOO_FILE` vs. `FOO`, and have the app read the value from `FOO_FILE` at runtime.  This file is then provided to the container safely as a secret, mounted securely at `/run/secrets/foo` by the Docker engine.

Some people to tricks to read these files and export to environment variables, but it's not recommended:

> Docker secrets do not set environment variables directly. This was a conscious decision, because environment variables can unintentionally be leaked between containers (for instance, if you use --link).

## Describe alternatives you've considered

The typical work-around is to use the `ENTRYPOINT` to run a shell script that reads the files and exports them into the environment, using the given variable name.  It can work.  But it would be better to use the suggested approach.

## Additional context

In terms of prior-art, [postgres already does this for their image](https://hub.docker.com/_/postgres):

> Docker Secrets
>
> As an alternative to passing sensitive information via environment variables, _FILE may be appended to some of the previously listed environment variables, causing the initialization script to load the values for those variables from files present in the container. In particular, this can be used to load passwords from Docker secrets stored in /run/secrets/<secret_name> files. For example:
>
> `$ docker run --name some-postgres -e POSTGRES_PASSWORD_FILE=/run/secrets/postgres-passwd -d postgres`
>
> Currently, this is only supported for POSTGRES_INITDB_ARGS, POSTGRES_PASSWORD, POSTGRES_USER, and POSTGRES_DB.

I think this same pattern could be extended to all the `supabase/*` images.

metadata.title: Support *_FILE for environment variable Docker Secrets in Supabase containers
metadata.creator: humphd

page_content:
# Feature request

Hi!
I'd love to be able to set a custom domain alias for my supabase project url, so that instead:

![Screenshot from 2022-02-21 22-41-46](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/156725/155029544-c233c0e5-3204-42ce-8e39-1516ce0adaae.png)

the users would see "Chose an account to continue to myproject.mydomain.org".

## Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

The google sign in will show: "Choose an account to continue to dalihgspogdhpodshhofdgogdssg.supabase.co which looks *completely like phishing* to anyone who received an 101 phishing-defense training.
**So this is not purely aesthetic problem, but a business one - imagine you prototype a product using Supabase (which it is great at) but you loose conversion because users are afraid to sign in** (being worried that some strange jfdsljfdsfuds.supabase.co people will get access to their precious Google account)! :fearful: 


## Describe the solution you'd like

Implement a basic custom domain support using LetsEncrypt free/automatic cert generation to secure it. Not hard to implement!

This would require:
 - [ ] setting custom domains in project settings
 - [ ] supabase proxy generating LetsEncrypt SSL cert to be able to serve the domain securely (alternatively, let user upload a commercial SSL cert)

## Describe alternatives you've considered

I did search GH issues to learn if you have considered custom domains and decided against them for *reasons*; but I could not find any such discussions.

## Additional context

None, thank you for great work and FLOSS generosity of your enterprise!

metadata.title: Allow custom domains for API & Storage
metadata.creator: marcinkoziej

page_content:
# Feature request

## Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

The URLs for static assets loaded by the studio container assume that the site is hosted at `/`, which breaks when you put it behind a proxy and change the URL.   For example, the way that fonts are loaded in https://github.com/supabase/supabase/blob/03eed357949495a8cd769a2f302e7f738adfdaa6/studio/pages/_app.tsx#L45

## Describe the solution you'd like

It would be great if we could define an environment variable in `docker-compose.yml` that specified an [`assetPrefix` to give to next.js](https://nextjs.org/docs/api-reference/next.config.js/cdn-support-with-asset-prefix) in the [next.config.js](https://github.com/supabase/supabase/blob/03eed357949495a8cd769a2f302e7f738adfdaa6/studio/next.config.js).  For example, it could work like so:

```
  studio:
    container_name: supabase-studio
    image: supabase/studio:latest
    ...
    environment:
      SUPABASE_URL: http://kong:8000
      STUDIO_PG_META_URL: http://meta:8080
      SUPABASE_ANON_KEY: ${ANON_KEY}
      SUPABASE_SERVICE_KEY: ${SERVICE_ROLE_KEY}
      # Define an assetPrefix to pass to next.config.js
      SUPABASE_STUDIO_ASSET_PREFIX: https://custom.domain.com/supabase
```

Now in `next.config.js`:

```js
module.exports = {
  // If defined, use the supplied prefix
  assetPrefix: process.env.SUPABASE_STUDIO_ASSET_PREFIX : '',
  ...
}
```

## Describe alternatives you've considered

Our current approach is to mount a volume and override `/usr/src/app/next.config.js` with our own version of the config, but this means we have to maintain a forked version.

metadata.title: Allow passing build arg for assetPrefix to studio next.config.js via docker-compose/Dockerfile
metadata.creator: humphd

page_content:
# Bug report

https://support.supabase.org/a/tickets/4724

From the user:
> About the SQL Editor bug, I've retrospected what I did differently that day and I think I've found the answer. I've had the SQL Editor open in 2 tabs. You are realtime saving the editor and possibly even storing some data locally. The important thing is: If you have more than 1 tab open with the SQL Editor, even if you edit only in 1 tab and use the other tabs only to read, your editor will always get corrupted.

This isn't just tab specific but I'm guessing the issue will also occur if 2 users are editing the same SQL snippet at once

There are multiple solutions to this imo
- Do not save snippet edits automatically, but rather through an explicit action (button / cmd + s etc) (as mentioned by the user)
  -  Lowest hanging fruit, not the best DX
  - Still needs syncing across tabs or at least some conflict resolution
- Snippets need to be real-time synced, such that saving on one browser tab should reflect the updates on another

metadata.title: SQL editor snippets save are conflicting when opened in separate browser tabs
metadata.creator: joshenlim

page_content:
# Chore

## Describe the chore

In order to tighten the security of a PostgreSQL instance, some suggest to revoke the permissions for the database and 'public' from the PUBLIC role and only grant privileges to specific roles (e.g. see https://wiki.postgresql.org/images/d/d1/Managing_rights_in_postgresql.pdf,  '6.9 Securing the default installation').

However, in the instances provided by Supabase, revoking the permissions from PUBLIC on the database and the 'public' schema breaks the PostgREST flow, because the 'authenticator' role no longer has the right to connect to the database.

It is still possible to simply GRANT CONNECTION permission to authetnicator, but it seems that it would be better if the default Supabase instances did that instead of relying on the permissions of the PUBLIC role. That way, Supabase will work regardless of whether someone tries to revoke the permissions from PUBLIC or not.

metadata.title: Grant CONNECT permission to authenticator, supabase_storage_admin and supabase_auth_admin roles explicitly so it does NOT rely on default permissions of the PUBLIC role
metadata.creator: chipilov

page_content:
# Bug report

## Describe the bug

It is possible to POST `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.sssZ` formatted values to column of type `timestamp`.

## Expected behavior

`timestamp` values with specified time zone should be rejected.

`timestamp` type is described as `Date and time (no time zone)`.

The ending `Z` in `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.sssZ (ISO 8601)` signifies UTC time zone.



## To Reproduce

```
// Request
curl -X POST 'https://SUBDOMAIN.supabase.co/rest/v1/users' \
-H "apikey: SUPABASE_KEY" \
-H "Authorization: Bearer SUPABASE_KEY" \
-H "Content-Type: application/json" \
-H "Prefer: return=representation" \
-d '{"id":"A","expires_at":"2022-01-05T00:00:00.001Z"}' // timestamp with .001Z

// Response
[
  {
    "id": "A",
    "created_at": "2022-01-05T06:00:47.37824",
    "expires_at": "2022-01-05T00:00:00.001" // Z is trimmed
  }
]

// Table editor
2022-01-05T00:00:00.001Z
```

```
// Request
curl -X POST 'https://SUBDOMAIN.supabase.co/rest/v1/users' \
-H "apikey: SUPABASE_KEY" \
-H "Authorization: Bearer SUPABASE_KEY" \
-H "Content-Type: application/json" \
-H "Prefer: return=representation" \
-d '{"id":"B","expires_at":"2022-01-05T00:00:00.000Z"}' // timestamp with .000Z

// Response
[
  {
    "id": "B",
    "created_at": "2022-01-05T05:58:31.230597",
    "expires_at": "2022-01-05T00:00:00" // .000Z is trimmed
  }
]

// Table editor
2022-01-05T00:00:00.000Z
```

## Additional context

Values of type `timestamp: Date and time (no time zone)` are eventually formatted as `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.sssZ`.

For example, setting value of `2022-01-05T18:05:02` in the table editor is shown as `2022-01-05T18:05:02.000Z` after refresh.

metadata.title: timestamp should reject ISO formatted date and time string
metadata.creator: hyunbinseo

page_content:
# Feature request

Expose PostgREST's `pre-request` config option to enable revoking long-lived tokens

## Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

This issue is based on this discussion: https://github.com/supabase/supabase/discussions/3205

There is more detail in the discussion linked above, but to summarize my use case:
1. I'd like to give long-lived JWTs to users of my webapp to use as API keys (akin to Stripe tokens or Supabase's `service_role` token)
2. I'd like to let users revoke and regenerate these tokens in my webapp's UI (so they can handle security issues on their end, like leaks or employee offboarding)
3. Supabase currently has no way to apply some security middleware (e.g. to check "is this request's token/claim in my list of revoked tokens?")

There are similar use cases, like this discussion https://github.com/supabase/supabase/discussions/2265 about wanting to revoke a `service_role` JWT (without needing to contact supabase support to do so).

## Describe the solution you'd like

As suggested in [PostgREST's docs on revocation](https://postgrest.org/en/v8.0/tutorials/tut1.html#bonus-topic-immediate-revocation), it would be nice to have a `pre-request` function that can run for all API requests. Maybe this option could be exposed in the Supabase Admin UI as a new API setting? Or, maybe this option could be specified in the database via [PostgREST's In-Database Configuration](https://postgrest.org/en/v8.0/configuration.html#in-database-configuration), though this method seems to require SUPERUSER.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

As described in the github discussion (https://github.com/supabase/supabase/discussions/3205), an alternative would be to add a revocation-check policy to every table, which is not-DRY and is error-prone due to the duplication, as well as bad for performance (if a single request makes many queries, or even a single query across many tables, the revocation check is evaluated repeatedly).

Other alternatives I can think of would be even worse (e.g. putting a revocation-checking proxy service in front of the Supabase API, sending all API requests to some database function that does revocation-checking then dispatches to other tables, e.g. `/rpc/dispatcher?table=profiles&payload=...`).

## Additional context

It looks like y'all are already working on exposing other PostgREST config options, like `db-schema` according to this discussion: https://github.com/supabase/supabase/discussions/1222

Implementing this feature request would hopefully share a lot of the same work and be not-too-onerous as a result! :crossed_fingers:

metadata.title: Expose PostgREST's `pre-request` config option to enable revoking long-lived tokens
metadata.creator: grschafer

page_content:
# Feature request

Currently, the hooks sent to an endpoint are unsigned.

As we note in the [RedwoodJS webhook documentation](https://redwoodjs.com/docs/webhooks):

> If you were to subscribe to one of these webhooks, you'd point it to an endpoint in your RedwoodJS api -- ie, a serverless function. But, because that function is out "in the cloud" you need to ensure that these run only when they should. That means your function must:
>
>* verify it comes from the place you expect
>* trust the party
>* know the payload sent in the hook hasn't been tampered with
>* ensure that the hook isn't reprocessed or replayed (sometimes)
>
>That is, you need to verify your incoming webhooks.

To ensure that incoming webhooks are trustworthy, we verify webhooks and offer several, common and popular [methods to verify](https://redwoodjs.com/docs/webhooks#webhook-verification) them using signature verification:

> Common signature verification methods are:
> 
> SHA256 (GitHub and Discourse)
> SHA1 (Vercel)
> JWT (Netlify)
> Timestamp Scheme (Stripe / Redwood default)
> Secret Key (Custom, Orbit)

## Describe the solution you'd like

We'd want to:

* declare the header to use (perhaps `x-supabase-signature` by default?) and which can be customized. 
* perhaps include over headers to include the app name or details (to distinguish webhooks from multiple Supabase apps/projects)
* Pick a singing method (SHA256, SHA1, JWT) etc (Or perhaps default to the most common, SHA256)
* Sign the payload
* Send the hook to the endpoint with the headers

### Question - signing and secret key:

* What is the signing secret key?
* If you use the JWT_SECRET in Supabase, does that a) expose that in can be queried
* But, since typically the client is setup with the `JWT_SECRET` that makes it very convenient to use as a verification secret value
* We'd *never* want to pass it along via a JWT verifier as that would expose it to the public potentially

### Question - when to sign:

* Would we want to sign the payload when queuing the hook (ie set headers and put that signature in the headers when adding to the `net.http_request_queue`
* Sign when actually sending the hook off the queue

In the case of a timestamp signed webhook, having it set before sent from q could mean it is out of date if perhaps you are scheduling for the future or some delay happens -- bu that could also be a good thing (See how Strrip uses timestamped hooks in their [best practices](https://stripe.com/docs/webhooks/best-practices) ) because:

>The TimestampScheme verifier not only signs the payload with a secret (SHA256), but also includes a timestamp to prevent replay attacks and a scheme (i.e., a version) to further protect webhooks.

> A replay attack is when an attacker intercepts a valid payload and its signature, then re-transmits them. To mitigate such attacks, third-parties like Stripe includes a timestamp in the Stripe-Signature header. Because this timestamp is part of the signed payload, it is also verified by the signature, so an attacker cannot change the timestamp without invalidating the signature. If the signature is valid but the timestamp is too old, you can have your application reject the payload.

Maybe a different newer hook was sent and now the old hook is out of date. The app wouldn't handle that stale hook and reject it thus keeping data consistent.

## Additional context

See:

* [RedwoodJS Webhook docs](https://redwoodjs.com/docs/webhooks#what-is-a-webhook)
* [Webhook.site lets you easily inspect, test and automate (with the visual Custom Actions builder, or WebhookScript) any incoming HTTP request or e-mail.](https://webhook.site/#!/)
* [What is a Webhook](https://simonfredsted.com/1583) by Simon Fredsted
* [About Webhooks](https://docs.github.com/en/developers/webhooks-and-events/about-webhooks) on GitHub
* [What are Webhooks? A simple guide to connection apps with webhooks](https://zapier.com/blog/what-are-webhooks/) on Zapier
* [What are Webhooks? Easy Explanation & Tutorial](https://snipcart.com/blog/what-are-webhooks-explained-example) on Snipcart
* [What are Webhooks and Why You Can’t Afford to Ignore Them](https://www.chargebee.com/blog/what-are-webhooks-explained/) on Charbee
* [What is a webhook: How they work and how to set them up](https://www.getvero.com/resources/webhooks/) on Vero

metadata.title: Support signed hooks that can be verified to come from a trusted Supabase project
metadata.creator: dthyresson

page_content:
# Feature request
I have stumbled upon creating complex join in supabase e.g. for composite key especially if this is hierarchically created.
Also if we can see here in the discussion https://github.com/supabase/supabase/discussions/2469
by default the naming will be long for joins thus making it error prone and not maintainable.

Solution: Renaming the foreign key constraints
New Problem: Development setup overhead which is writing another sql to rename the constraint that depends on how many joins the table will have.

metadata.title: Add a view editor for easily naming foreign keys...
metadata.creator: sandbox-apps

page_content:
# Feature request
Right now we only have Table Editor for concrete tables so we can directly view the data in supabase

## Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
Problem is we do not have table view editor for `VIEWS`.
Typically we want to create complex table query like `relationship`, but doesn't scale well in the frontend code where you will add this complex queries to your code. So the solution is to create a custom view and add that SQL query so in the client side the complexity has been abstract.

## Describe the solution you'd like
Add a view editor page like table editor so we can view the output and navigate with paginate just like the table editor page.
We can also add a form page to create a view so we don't bloat the SQL page with different kinds of SQL Commands

metadata.title: Table View Editor for Creating View instead of table
metadata.creator: sandbox-apps

page_content:
# Bug report

## Describe the bug

I setup local dev a while ago, and now implementing auth. However when I call `supabaseClient.auth.signUp(...)` and look at the results in the net panel of dev tools, I see a result code error 500 and contents `{code: 500, msg: "Database error finding user", ...}` when posting to `http://localhost:8000/auth/v1/signup`

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/127349/117514139-09b07f00-af48-11eb-80ac-d6b9171f18aa.png)

## System information

- OS: MacOS (latest)
- Browser: Chrome (latest)
- Version of supabase-js: 1.11.9
- Version of Node.js: v14.16.1

metadata.title: Database error finding user (when creating one), supabase-auth accessing public.users not auth.users
metadata.creator: sroussey

page_content:
# Feature request

## Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

I have enabled to `POSTGIS_TIGER_GEOCODER`, but whenever I use the its geocoding functionality no results are returned. I believe this is because while the extension is enabled, the census data it uses to geocode is not loaded. See the PostGIS Tiger docs for more info: http://postgis.net/docs/postgis_installation.html#install_tiger_geocoder_extension.

The query I'm using to test is:
```
select tiger.geocode('... my address ...');
```
which returns
```
 geocode
---------
(0 rows)
```

## Describe the solution you'd like

Documentation on how to load the census data and/or automatically loading it when enabling the extension.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

## Additional context

metadata.title: PostGIS Tiger: Data not loaded to use geocode function
metadata.creator: jaredramirez

page_content:
As suggested by Nicolo, we should standardize the error responses coming from GoTrue, postgres, and realtime (and any other/future APIs) so that it's better DX when writing a client,

We can make this change on the servers themselves, but since postgrest and gotrue are fully/partially external may be harder to change, it might be an option to transform the errors within the client libraries/supabase-js, could be messy?

Nicolo also dropped this as a reference: http://spec.openapis.org/oas/v3.0.3#openapi-specification

metadata.title: Standardize Error Responses across APIs
metadata.creator: awalias
